alert.note: Alert for Dawson; Gosper; Greeley; Sherman; Valley (Nebraska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Hastings (North Central Kansas and South Central Nebraska)
info.headline: Heat Advisory issued August 19 at 3:56PM CDT until August 19 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Hastings
info.description: ...HEAT ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM CDT THIS EVENING... ...HEAT ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM NOON MONDAY TO 10 PM CDT WEDNESDAY... * WHAT...For the Heat Advisory ending at 8 PM this evening, heat index values around 105 to 110 are expected. For the Heat Advisory in effect from noon on Monday through Wednesday evening, heat index values around 100 to 105 are expected. * WHERE...Valley, Greeley, Sherman, Dawson and Gosper Counties. * WHEN...For the first Heat Advisory, until 8 PM CDT this evening. For the second Heat Advisory, from noon Monday to 10 PM CDT Wednesday. * IMPACTS...Hot temperatures and high humidity may cause heat illnesses to occur. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS...While this prolonged stretch of heat will last well into next week, today will feature the lightest winds, and thus the least relief from the stifling conditions. Stronger southwest winds closer to 15 to 20 MPH will prevail Monday through Wednesday. Although it will be hot again Sunday, heat index readings are expected to remain slightly below 105 degrees and thus there is no Advisory for Sunday at this time.
info.instruction: Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles under any circumstances. Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location. Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.
